document.text: Detecting cosmic rays using radio waves is a technique
ing the relation between the parameters of this function
and the EAS properties. These semi-analytical expressions are extracted from a set of microscopic simulations,
thus benefiting from their precision. If we have obtained
these across different primary types, -energies and shower
geometries, we will only ever need to run a single microscopic simulation for a certain geometry in order to
synthesise the emission for showers with arbitrary longitudinal evolution profiles with the same geometry.
Here we perform a simulation study using 600 vertical
air showers simulated with CORSIKA together with its
plugin CoREAS for the radio emission [14, 15].
heavily researched in the 1960s and 1970s (see for example [1, 2]). It was, however, abandoned in favour of other
methods, which were able to extract information more reliably. In the past two decades the field has experienced a
revival thanks to the increased computational power and
modern digital signal processing techniques [3, 4]. Today,
the radio technique has fully matured up to a point where
it can be used alongside existing detection methods.
A unique advantage of the radio detection method is
the low cost associated with the deployment of the experiments. This makes it easy to deploy the large-scale
arrays required to detect the highest energy cosmic rays,
the flux of which drops to fewer then one particle per
per century [5]. Instead of measuring the particles
directly, we observe the cascade of secondaries they produce upon interacting in the atmosphere, in an event
referred to as an extensive air shower (EAS).
These EAS produce impulsive radio emission over a
this simulation set we extract scaling relations that depend only on the
of the shower. Other dependencies are taken care of by rescaling the emission using the
longitudinal profile. In this process we make use of air
shower universality [20–24], which states that showers in
the same stage of development have similar electron and
positron distributions. The authors of [20] found their
parametrisations to be accurate within 10% for the intermediate stages, which are the most relevant for the
observed radio emission, so we expect template synthesis
to have an accuracy of the same order.
The rest of this work is organised as follows. First in
Below 100 MHz the emission is coherent for antennas
within a couple of 100m from the shower axis, meaning
the power scales with the square of the number of particles present in the cascade and as such with the square
of energy of the primary cosmic ray [4]. On top of this,
it has been shown that using radio detection techniques
we are able to extract the atmospheric depth at which
the EAS has the highest number of particles, denoted as
Still, there are hints that there is much more to be
Section II we introduce the tools and conventions used
in template synthesis. In Section III we present the template synthesis method. Next in Section IV we apply the
method to our simulation set of vertical EAS and synthesise radio pulses filtered over two different frequency
bands. The first one, 20 to 500 MHz, is the range we
target for the application of our approach. Next to this,
we investigate the 30 to 80 MHz band, which represents
a typical range for current cosmic-ray radio experiments.
We then present metrics to gauge the accuracy of template synthesis in Section V. In Section VI we highlight
some notable results and physical interpretations coming
from the template synthesis approach. We conclude in
Section VII with some final observations and a roadmap
for the further development of the method.
learned from radio data [11, 12]. Two interesting parameters are the width and asymmetry of the particle number
longitudinal evolution, as they could help us distinguish
between the predictions of different hadronic interaction
models and even separate protons from other primary
ASPECTS OF RADIO EMISSION FROM EAS
Unfortunately, analyses are hindered by the requirement of performing a large number of simulations. Current state-of-the-art Monte-Carlo-based simulation codes
Throughout this work we will use the longitudinal
calculating radio emission from air showers, such as

CoREAS [14, 15] and ZHAireS [16, 17], are computationally very expensive. The time required to run these microscopic models puts stringent limitations on the number of simulations that can be generated for each observation. Models based on macroscopic quantities exist, such

distributions are also not accounted for. All these aspects
hybrid model which characterises the radio signal in a
single antenna using a parameterised function for the
emission. The goal is then to find expressions describ-
CoREAS, the emission from a particle is counted towards
a slice if the particle starts its track within that slice
Besides the emission in each slice, we also have the
number of particles recorded in each of them. This information is crucial in order to synthesise across primary
energies and particle types, as this number can vary dramatically between them. Thus from a sliced simulation
we have both the radio emission

we have both the radio emission ⃗
Eslice and the total number of electrons and positrons Nslice in each slice.
We know the radio emission from EAS is mostly generated by two independent mechanisms [4]. The dominant one in air is due to the time-varying transverse
currents arising from the deflection of the charged particles in the geomagnetic field in combination with their
friction with atmospheric molecules, hence the name
emission. The other one is recognised as the
Askaryan-effect, which occurs because of a time-varying
excess of negative particles at the shower front. Therefore
this is often referred to as
As the geomagnetic and charge-excess emission have
The atmospheric slicing performed for template

the shower age are taken into account.

Equation (2) to each component and fit the result using
Equations (4) and (5), respectively. If a particular slice
contains no particles, we exclude it from further analysis.

While the previous sections highlight the procedure
with which we apply the template synthesis method, here
we wish to delve deeper in some notable aspects we encountered.
First of all we want to come back to Figure 2 and the
realisation that the pulse shape in each slice depends on
of the shower. Additionally, within a slice the
spectra from different showers arrange themselves in a
this can be understood from the perspective of shower
in a given slice, or more accurately the
between the atmospheric depth of the slice and
of the shower, is a proxy for the age of the shower
in that slice. The age of a shower represents the state of
its development in the atmosphere, and as such the state
of the currents responsible for the radio emission. Several
properties of the air shower have been shown to correlate
strongly with shower age, such as energy, angular and
lateral distributions of electrons and positrons [20, 21].
For this reason, we presume we can simplify the problem further. In the current version of template synthesis
FIG. 9. The amplitude frequency spectra from the geomagnetic component of the radio emission from 3 different showers, in the slice at 600 g
function (overlayed line of the same colour as the spectra)

apparent. For example, at lower frequencies the parametrisation undershoots the geomagnetic spectra, while around 250
MHz the spectra start overshooting slightly. By rescaling the
emission in every slice, we can retain these trends.
we consider the spectral functions to be unique for every
slice, allowing for maximal complexity in the method.
Given that shower age is the determining factor for pulse
shape, it should be possible to reformulate the spectral
Then, the spectral functions are no longer specific to a
does capture the general trend for all amplitude spectra,

explains why we do not use the parametrised amplitude
frequency spectrum for the target shower. By rescaling
the emission from an origin shower, we can preserve these
We are also aware of other approaches to reduce computational cost for simulations such as MGMR3D [18]
slice, which reduces the number of parameters to be saved
significantly. Furthermore, this formulations lends itself
much better to generalising towards and across other,
Another avenue that could be explored would be to
look at different parametrisations of the amplitude frequency spectrum.
Also including other shower fluctuations explicitly, would add more dimensions in which
template synthesis can work and thus probably improve
the quality as well. It is even possible this will be required in order to obtain a more general formulation of
the spectral functions, as we discussed above.
In order to arrive at a better parametrisation, we will
and Radio-Morphing [34, 35]. The latter approach was
developed specifically for very inclined air showers, for
which the source of the radio emission is much further
away than for vertical showers, simplifying the problem
considerably. We expect template synthesis to converge
towards Radio-Morphing as the zenith angle increases, in
the sense that we will obtain similar scaling relations in
that regime. We plan to test this convergence as well as
compare template synthesis to the macroscopic approach
of MGMR3D once template synthesis is capable of handling all geometries.
Lastly, we also want to mention recent breakthroughs
first need a better understanding of the coherency conditions of the radio emission. While on the Cherenkov cone
we observe a strong signal across the whole frequency
band, away from it the amplitude spectra can exhibit interesting patterns. Recently it has become clear these
are not solely due to numerical noise in the Monte Carlo
simulations, as similar effects have been observed in results from macroscopic codes. While our paramatrisation
in interpolation schemes to calculate the radio emission
at arbitrary positions on the ground [36]. We envision
combining this pulse interpolation with template synthesis in the future, in order to provide a complete scheme to
synthesise the radio emission from an EAS at any chosen
We presented a novel approach to synthesise the radio emission from EAS, called template synthesis. The
sults show that the smaller frequency band yields smaller
scatter in synthesis quality, around 5% down from 10%.
This is probably due to functional form with which we
parametrise the amplitude frequency spectra, as it starts
to break down over larger frequency intervals. Investigation of other functional forms is something we defer to
later work, once we have applied template synthesis to
We showed that after bias correction, the method
method considers the radio emission in every antenna,
coming from slices of constant atmospheric depth separately. It uses semi-analytical relations, which are extracted from a set of microscopic CoREAS simulations, to
rescale the amplitude frequency spectra from each slice.
At the end of the process the contributions from all slices
are summed up to recover the complete signal. Other
modifications, such as minor bias corrections, are also
In this work we applied template synthesis to a set of
works well for vertical air showers, if the change in
between origin and target shower is not too large. For
the frequency band of 30 to 80 MHz, the synthesis has
an accuracy better than 5% if we restrict
template synthesis achieves an accuracy better than 10%
The poorer accuracy seems to be the result of deviations
from the real trace away from the main pulse. The impact of this in practical applications will be the subject
The results indicate we are limited by shower universality, or more precisely the shower fluctuations we did
600 vertical air showers, simulated using CORSIKA with
the CoREAS plugin, as a proof-of-principle. From this
simulation set we extracted the semi-analytical relations
by parameterising the amplitude frequency spectrum in
each antenna and in every slice. The parameters of this
function exhibit a quadratic dependence on the
the shower. By fitting this dependence, we obtained the
spectral functions needed to account for changes in the
radio-emission pulse shape associated with the ageing of
air showers and with which we could synthesise the radio
emission from an air shower with an arbitrary longitudinal profile.
In order to quantify the performance of the method, we
not account for explicitly. These fluctuations will introduce scatter in the synthesis quality plots, as they differ

compared the results of template synthesis to the pulses
simulated by CoREAS. We used every shower from our
simulation set as the origin shower to synthesise the emission from all other showers in the set and scored the result
using two different metrics. When doing so, we observed
a bias which was linear with the shift in
from origin to target shower. As we only looked at one geometry
here, we opted to not look deeper into this effect. Rather
we fitted this bias with a linear function as function of
∆Xmax and corrected the final result of template synthesis for it.
